conclusion: Understanding the problem involves determining wave direction and speed from two figures.
Figure 1 is a snapshot of the wave at t=2 seconds with x-axis from 0 to 6 meters and y-axis from -A to A.
There are two full wavelengths in Figure 1, so the wavelength λ is 3 meters.
Figure 2 shows the vibration of the particle at x=2 meters over time from t=0 to t=6 seconds.
There are two full cycles in 6 seconds in Figure 2, so the period T is 3 seconds.
Wave speed v is calculated as v = λ / T = 3 / 3 = 1 meter per second.
The problem asks for the direction of wave propagation based on the figures.
In Figure 1, at t=2 seconds, the wave is at maximum positive displacement at x=1 meter and maximum negative at x=4 meters.
In Figure 2, at t=2 seconds, the particle at x=2 meters is at y=0 and moving upwards.
If a particle is moving upwards when the wave passes, the wave is moving to the right.
The wave is propagating to the right since the particle at x=2 meters is moving upwards at t=2 seconds.
